text: A lush campsite, in the woods. A smattering of RV’s and campers, a few TENTS, spaced out from each other for priv Legend: 1980 VIOLET (7) steps out of a small CAMPER, heading away as h MOTHER leans out of the door. VIOLET’S MOTHER Where are you going, Violet?
Just to pick some flowers! VIOLET’S MOTHER Don’t wander too far!

Violet moves down the path, stopping to look at some WILD FLOWERS growing beside her. She glances up, seeing SEVERA RV’S and MOTOR HOMES in a cluster, just visible off the p We don’t know it yet, but these belong to the TRUE KNOT. Unaware of their danger, Violet heads further down the pa

Violet emerges into a clearing on the banks of a quiet, pristine river. Sunlight reflecting off the water, lovely wildflowers growing by the bank... She's startled to see a WOMAN sitting by the water, almos hidden by the overgrowth. Holding a fistful of FLOWERS, throwing pedals into the stream as she sings...

My wild Irish Rose / The sweetest flower that grows / You may search everywhere / But none can compare with my wild Irish Rose... She is beautiful, dressed in flowing, strange clothes and black TOP HAT. She is ROSE THE HAT (looks 30's, but is so much older). She turns to Violet, smiling sweetly.
Well hi there.  2. Violet stares at Rose’s flowers. BRIGHTER, more COLORFUL the wildflowers she’s found...
Where did you find those?
Oh, these? I know all the secret places. You want one? Violet doesn’t answer. Studies Rose’s face. She has a swe demeanor, a KIND, EARNEST SMILE...

Oh... you’re wondering why I’m wearing such a funny hat. Well I'll tell you. I always wear this hat. So much it’s part of my name now. My friends, my very best friends, they just call me “Rose the Hat.” You can call me that, now that we're friends.
I like it. It looks like a magician’s hat.
It is! It’s a magic hat, wanna see? Rose removes her hat. Violet watches, her wariness fading

Take a look. Nothing in my hat, nothing up my sleeves... Violet STEPS FORWARD again, so that she can see inside th hat. It’s EMPTY. Rose turns it over, shaking it for effec A SNAPPING BRANCH draws Violet’s attention. She turns, se a MAN lurking at the edge of the woods. STARING AT HER. H CROW (40's, dressed in dirty clothes.) PERFECTLY STILL.
Don’t worry, he’s my friend. You're missing the trick! Reach inside. Violet hesitates... and then reaches her hand out, into t hat... pulling up a HANDFUL OF BEAUTIFUL FLOWERS.
Wow... they’re so pretty --
Because they’re special. Speaking of special... you’re a little magic too, aren’t you. Rose reaches into the hat, her hand disappearing from vie
The flower in my hand. What color is it? (off Violet's hesitation) It’s okay, honey. You won’t scare me. I’m not like mom and dad.
Purple. Rose smiles, lifting up a GORGEOUS PURPLE FLOWER. Another SNAPPING TWIG, and Violet looks. There are MORE PEOPLE now, standing at the periphery of the woods.

Violet. Like you. She turns. She doesn’t remember telling Rose her name... Rose turns over the hat, and FLOWERS POUR OUT OF IT onto ground. Violet’s eyes light up. She stoops, picking up a of them. Rose does the same -- and EATS a flower, right o the stem.
You don’t eat flowers!
Oh, but you do.
But these are special.

The special ones taste best. More SNAPS, and Violet turns to see SIX PEOPLE, members o the TRUE KNOT, watching from all around them. Flanking he They are Crow, BARRY THE CHUNK (40's, heavy), GRAMPA FLIC (ancient), APRON ANNIE (30's) and SILENT SAREY (50's).
I should get back to my mom... She starts to pull away, but CAN’T. She looks down: ROSE’ HAND GRIPS HER FOREARM. TIGHT.

Stay a while. See more magic. Violet starts to PULL against Rose’s grip, but it is VICE LIKE. Behind her, THE TRUE KNOT ADVANCES ON HER. SILENT. Their movement STRANGE, INHUMAN - closing in on all sides

You are a special little thing, aren’t you. She squeezes Violet’s arm as the pale faces speed up, barreling toward her silently. Rose’s fingernails DRAW BL on the girl’s forearm. And Rose is STILL SMILING.

Violet's mother walks up the path, a little concerned. VIOLET’S MOTHER Vi? Violet! Silence. She glances down at the wildflowers growing by t path, frowning to herself. Behind her, we see the TRUE KN RV’S DRIVING AWAY. She barely glances at them. VIOLET’S MOTHER (CONT’D) (panic growing) Vil Violet! Violet! As her panic grows, the small group of RV’s exit the campground unnoticed as she heads deeper in the woods, calling for a daughter that will not answer.

Snow. Snow as far as we can see, so bright in the moonlig it almost seems to be giving off its own light. The camer floats above it, tilting up to reveal: THE OVERLOOK HOTEL. Half-buried in the snowfall.

The camera follows a boy on a tricycle. We recognize him immediately... YOUNG DANNY TORRANCE (5) riding his tricyc down the familiar hallways. Turning corners, moving fast.  5. He comes to a stop in front of a specific room. ROOM 217. gradually realize why he stopped, and why he stares... TH DOORKNOB IS TURNING. SOOOOO SLOWLY... As he watches, the door CREEPS OPEN, revealing ABYSSAL DARKNESS WITHIN. And then, just as slowly, a FIGURE START MATERIALIZE IN THE INKY BLACKNESS...

head_text.subj: A GROTESQUE WOMAN, NAKED, GREEN WITH ROT, DRIPPING WET, J
BARELY STEPPING OUT OF THE DARK WHEN --

text: INT. DANNY’S BEDROOM, FLORIDA - NIGHT -- DANNY'S EYES FLY OPEN. He BOLTS UP in bed, gasping fro the nightmare. COVERED WITH SWEAT, his dream still fresh. catches his breath, and quietly climbs out of bed.

A door, the name “DANNY” displayed in construction paper, opens as Danny steps into the small condominium. He heads toward the BATHROOM at the end of the hall. The door is CLOSED as he approaches, and he slows down. Surprised to see it closed... He steps toward the door, cautious. Listening. And then, faintly...

head_text.subj: WE HEAR A SOUND THROUGH THE DOOR. A QUIET SLOSHING OF
WATER... LIKE SOMEONE SHIFTING IN A BATHTUB.

text: Danny hesitates. Afraid to open the door, but telling him that he’s being silly -- it’s all in his head... He slowl turns the knob, and OPENS THE DOOR, REVEALING: A WOMAN, IN THE TUB, SITTING IN THE DARK. Lit only by MOONLIGHT. Obscured by the shower curtain. She slowly rea up, pulling the curtain back. We know who she is: MRS. MASSEY. The WOMAN IN THE TUB. Her skin green and bloated, her hands purple with coagulated blood. Her eyes dead and white, like a fish’s belly. We can almost SMELL putrid rot as she GRINS AT DANNY -- The filthy water SLOSHES as she slowly STANDS, naked, her body waterlogged and rotting. A purple foot LIFTS from th water, STEPPING ONTO THE BATHMAT. Danny’s bladder LETS GO, a puddle forming at his feet. She LUMBERS TOWARD HIM as Danny CLOSES THE DOOR, stepping back into the hall.  6. He stares, wide-eyed and terrified as A SHADOW APPEARS UN

head_text.subj: THE DOOR. FILTHY WATER LEAKING OUT AS THE DOORKNOB SLOWLY

text: Danny COVERS HIS EYES, trying to WILL IT AWAY, even as he hears DEAD FINGERNAILS SCRATCHING ON THE DOOR --

head_text.subj: A HAND FALLS ONTO HIS SHOULDER, AND HE SPINS, SCREAMING -

text: Into the face of WENDY TORRANCE (30's, exhausted. )
Hey! Hey! It’s okay, it’s okay... He RUNS into her arms, she holds him, alarmed and perplex
Wendy PULLS a fresh pair of pajama bottoms onto Danny.
There, all dry. What happened? Danny doesn’t answer. Just stares ahead, CATATONIC. WENDY (CONT’D) Danny, you have to talk to me. You haven’t talked since we left that... place. Please, Doc. Please.

Wendy steps down the hall slowly, toward the bathroom doo Steeling herself. Summoning a familiar courage -- a coura she learned at the Overlook. She reaches the doorknob, and only hesitates a moment bef opening the door and turning on the light. The room is empty. Nothing in the tub, nothing out of the ordinary. She exhales. She’s about to leave, hand on the light switch, when she sees -- TWO SHAPES ON THE BATHMAT. WET DEPRESSIONS. FOOTPRINTS.
Danny sits on a bench, looking out at the marina. Exhaust
So you ain’t talkin’, huh Doc? Reveal DICK HALLORANN (late 50’s, black) sitting beside h

Weren’t talking much first time I met you, neither. Little boy, set to spend a long winter at that rotten old place, just him and his mommy and daddy -- daddy’s dark as that boy is bright and boy, is he bright -- he’s Shining like fire in the one place - the worst place - for a boy who Shines. (beat) You remember the first time we really talked? When I spoke up inside your head? Danny nods. Dick smiles. And then, Dick keeps talking... his mouth doesn’t move. He speaks IN DANNY’S MIND.
Made you feel good, right? Knowing you weren’t alone?
Daddy tried to kill me. Dick notices that Danny used his “outside” voice, and fol suit. No longer talking in his head.
It wasn’t all him, you gotta know. That place fed his dark, like it fed on your light. And he had some light in him, too. Just like you got some dark. We all got both --
It’s not done with me.

It ever strike you funny, how I showed up when I did? When you needed me? Someone did that for me too. My gramma taught me and I tried to teach you and some day, Danny Torrance, you'll teach someone else-
I won't.
Oh you won’t, huh.
I won’t Shine, I mean. No more. It’s dangerous.
Reckon it is, sometimes.
She found me. She’1l come back and come back until she gets me.
You're right. Overlook’s condemned. Boarded up. They’re starving old ghosts and they’re reaching out for you. Won’t stop with her, either.
Pictures in a book. You said they were just pictures in a book, and they couldn’t hurt me.
Thought they was.
But they aren’t. They’re real.

Some things, dark things, the Shining’s like food. They're mosquitos, landing for blood. (beat) The Overlook, it was always just pictures to me, but I didn’t Shine like you. Nobody Shines like you. So you, in that damn hotel... you was like a million-watt battery, all plugged in, and it ate it up. You made it real, started soon as you walked through the door.

Can't do nothin’ about that, I’m sorry to tell you but you’re not a child, you're older now, much older in a way, and you gotta hear this. World’s a hungry place and the darkest things are the hungriest and they'll eat what Shines. Swarm it. Like mosquitos, or leeches. (MORE )
Can’t do nothing ‘bout that. What you can do is turn what they come for against them. Danny looks up at Dick. His old eyes are sad, weary.

My grandfather, he was a mean sonofabitch. Dark inside, same type of dark as your dad. Beat me senseless, and my gramma too, and when he died I danced but he kept on comin’ back. Standing in my room, suit all grey and stinking, from whatever mold was growing on him in that box. One day he grabbed me and he was real. His nails were overgrown, growing long in the grave and they cut me, Doc. Cut me deep. And Gramma... she taught me a trick. Gave me a present. He reaches into his coat, and removes A SMALL METAL LOCKB Very old, rusted. And, a KEY. On a chain.
I want you to know this box. Inside and out. Don’t just look at it; touch it. Stick your nose inside and see if there’s a smell. Know every corner. Every single thing.
Why?

Because you’re gonna build one just like it in your mind. One even more special. So next time that bitch comes ‘round, you’ll be ready. (beat) Let’s get you back to momma. Wendy’1l worry and she shouldn’t have to worry another day in her life; that woman’s paid that debt. They stand from the bench, walking back toward the shops. Further out, Wendy is looking wildly around as she SPOTS Danny approaching. She rushes toward him, relieved... We realize DANNY IS WALKING ALONE. DICK IS GONE.
There you are! Where did you go???  10. She hugs him as we PAN OFF of them, resting on a TATTERED MISSING POSTER ON A LIGHT POST... A POSTER OF VIOLET’S FA
Danny and Wendy sit on the couch, snuggling as they watch BUGS BUNNY CARTOON. Wendy laughs at the show, Danny smile Content. BETTER. And then, he looks up. Toward the hallwa
I have to pee. He hops up, and Wendy watches him go. A little concerned.

Danny turns the corner. Looking at the BATHROOM DOOR. It’ SLIGHTLY OPEN... and he sees what he knew he’d see. MRS. MASSEY, in the tub, BARELY VISIBLE through the door. He takes a breath, and walks toward the bathroom. As he nears, she SITS UP, GRINNING WITH HER ROTTEN TEETH. Danny steps into the door as she CLIMBS TO HER FEET, filth and water dripping from her.
Hi Mrs. Massey. (beat) I brought you a present. He CLOSES THE DOOR, we PULL BACK. SLOW. After a few beats MRS. MASSEY SCREAMS.
Wendy looks up as Danny returns. Calm, casual.
You okay, Doc?
Yeah, mom. I’m okay. He climbs onto the couch, resting his head on his mother’ shoulder. She can tell... HE’S OKAY. TRULY OKAY. And for first time in a long time, Danny SMILES.

INT. DEENIE’S BEDROOM - MORNING DAN TORRANCE (mid 20’s now) awakes with a start. Pale, sweaty. His face BRUISED AND SWOLLEN, fighting through on the worst (and last) hangovers of his life. Legend: 2000 He’s in a FILTHY APARTMENT, a dirty mattress on a dirty floor. He COUGHS, dry-heaving as he holds his throbbing h He rolls over, and stops as he sees -- DEENIE (early 20's, frail and sickly) asleep next to him. Also naked. He stares, trying to remember --
Blurry flashes. Hazy memories. Dan, downing a shot of whiskey. And another. Deenie, holding onto him while he shoots pool.
(slurring) What’s your name again, Cutey...

Dan stares at her. There’s VOMIT next to her mouth, stain her pillow. As the sight and smell hit him -- INT. DEENIE’S BATHROOM - MOMENTS LATER Dan PUKES into the toilet, spitting out a vile mix of bil and whiskey. Fumbles for the handle, barely manages a flu He THROWS water on his face, looking up in the mirror AND SEEING THE CUTS AND BRUISES. One eye almost SWOLLEN SHUT. reaches up, perplexed. Touching the wounds...

-- More whiskey. A LARGE MAN trying to pull Deenie away f him. Dan, getting in the man’s face. A PUNCH that lands D on the ground. Spitting out BLOOD, getting to his feet - familiar DARKNESS in his eyes. -- A hand, grabbing a BILLIARD BALL. Dan, SMASHING THE BA into the man’s head. Straddling him now, as others SCRAMB TO BREAK UP THE FIGHT. Dan’s hand, smashing the ball into man’s head AGAIN. And AGAIN. And AGAIN.  12.
(between blows) You gonna take - your - medicine --
Dan STUMBLES, catching himself on the dresser. Looks down his BLOODY, BRUISED KNUCKLES. HIS HANDS SWOLLEN.

Oh god... He looks back at the sleeping girl, and then at THE WHITE POWDER, STILL ARRANGED IN SLOPPY LINES, on the nightstand beside her. NEXT TO THE EMPTY WHISKEY BOTTLE. INT. DEENIE’S BEDROOM - THE PREVIOUS NIGHT Dan PULLS HARD from the whiskey, WINCING as Deenie SNORTS LINE OF COKE from the nightstand.
Holy shit, I think you killed him. What if you killed him. I hope you killed him. I hope you killed him, you hear me? Deenie, STRADDLING HIM NOW.

Lemme kiss it better. She kisses him, hard, pushing him back onto the mattress. INT. DEENIE’S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Dan STUMBLES out, pulling his clothes on. Looking at the BLOOD ON HIS SHIRT. Not all of it his... And then he realizes something. He pulls out his WALLET.. CASH. Digs through his pockets. NOTHING.

Fuck. Fuck... He turns his pockets out, frantic now. All of his money, gone, probably snorted by the naked girl in the other roo HER PURSE. There, on the table. Open. Dan stares at it, a after a long pause, he moves toward it.  13. He opens her wallet, looking through. There’s CASH there, maybe $100. Tens and twenties, crumpled... AND FOOD STAMPS. A pile of food stamps. He slowly removes the cash, conflicted. Looking back thro the open bedroom door, where she snores softly. He POCKET THE CASH, heading toward the door when --
Mommy? He stops cold. Turns. Standing in the doorway to another bedroom is a TODDLER, maybe 18 months. Staring at him. Da DEFLATES a little. Confused, concerned... humiliated.
What’s your name, hero? The kid just stares at him.
Please tell me you came from next door. Or down the hall...

Momma... Dan sighs. Oh, shit. He goes to the kid. Picks him up -- AND SEES THE BRUISES on the boy’s arms. The kind you get being GRABBED. REALLY HARD. He carries the boy into the bedroom, placing him next to Deenie.

Momma! He cuddles against her, and even in her stupor, Deenie wr a hand around him. Dan watches, heart breaking a little. He makes his way toward the door, stopping one last time her purse. Looking at the food stamps, the little boy cud up next to Deenie... And at the CASH in his hand.
You can put her money back, Doc. You can do that much. He looks up. Dick is standing in the shadows, HIDDEN.
She took mine. Probably spent it on the coke --  14.

Doc. Dan stares him down. After a moment, tucks the money in h pocket. He turns back, looking at Deenie and the boy. Squints, concentrating. For a moment, a FLASH of -- THE LOCK BOX, with the rusty lock.
Oh no, Doc. You can put things from the Overlook away in boxes, but not memories. Never those. They’re the real ghosts, you take ‘em with you. Dan stares at him defiantly, and walks out the door.

INT. ABRA’S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - EVENING DAVID (30's) and LUCY (30’s) turn the corner, following t sound of PIANO MUSIC. Stilted, promising... YOUNG ABRA (5 years old, adorable), sits at the piano in the living roo
Time for bed, Abra.
A little more??
No sweetie, big day tomorrow.
Birthday party!
That's right. But for now, bedtime. INT. ABRA’S HOUSE, ABRA’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER David and Lucy tuck Abra into bed. Handing her a STUFFED BUNNY, which Abra CUDDLES happily.
Abba’s five! Happy birthday Abba!

Not just yet. Goodnight sweetie. They leave her tucked in, closing the door softly.  15. INT. ABRA’S HOUSE, MASTER BEDROOM - LATER David and Lucy are fast asleep. Slowly stirred by a sound PIANO MUSIC, echoing through the dark house. INT. ABRA’S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER David and Lucy make their way down the stairs, the music LOUDER NOW. It seems Abra’s snuck out of bed, and gone ba to the piano. As they turn the corner, they STOP COLD. There is no one in the room. But THE PIANO IS PLAYING, th same song Abra was struggling with earlier...
ANDI STEINER (15, sharp and pretty) sits in the dark thea Munching on candy as an older BUSINESSMAN (50s) makes his down the aisle, sitting next to her. She doesn’t look up from her candy as he sits.
Andi?
That’s right.
You're prettier than your picture.
You’re older than yours. He looks around, a little nervous.
So are we staying here or going somewhere?

Don’t you want to watch the movie? He frowns. But soon softens as she SNUGGLES UP to him, la her head on his shoulder. His HAND finds her THIGH. We pull back to reveal ROSE and CROW, sitting a few rows back. Not watching the movie. Watching ANDI.  16.
I don’t see what the fuss is about. Chat room romance. A little gross, but not interesting.
Watch. It’s interesting, I promise.
It better be. Because she’s not all that steamy -
There she goes. They watch as Andi PUTS HER LIPS TO HER DATE’S EAR.
Aren’t you tired? Sleep. The man’s head instantly DROPS to his chest. He’s OUT COL She lifts his LIMP HAND off her thigh with disgust, and fishes out his wallet. Starts PULLING CASH, credit cards.
Okay.
Wait. This is the best part. I’ve watched her do it three times now and it never gets old. Andi pulls a PEARL-HANDLED KNIFE from her purse.
Sleep deeper. Deep as you can. The pain you'll feel is only a dream. What will the pain be?
A dream. She puts her arm around him, and quietly SLASHES TWO TINY into his cheek. The blood FLOWS. He doesn’t even FLINCH.

You can explain a lost wallet, when your wife asks, but you can’t explain this. This, you see every day in the mirror. Every time you see it, you’ll say it out loud... “I like little girls.” She finishes cutting, leaning closer to the sleeping man.  17.
You'll say it out loud.
Out loud.

And the next time you go looking for a little girl online, you’1l remember that time you got bit by a rattlesnake. A rattlesnake in a blue skirt and white blouse, whose face is a blank. She kisses his bloody cheek, standing from her chair, qui leaving the theater. Rose and Crow watch, impressed.
That is interesting.
Andi walks in the afternoon sun. The street is crowded, s in a city. Behind her, CROW approaches.
“Scuse me, miss? Miss! She ignores him, walking faster.
You left something in the theater -
You wanna leave me alone. Crow STOPS. Blinks. Suddenly UNSURE of himself, as if he FORGOT WHY HE WAS CHASING HER. Andi turns to leave when - ROSE GRABS HER ARM.
Well hi there. Andi stares at her.
You want to let me go.
Oh no, sweetie. No I don’t.

Dan wakes up under the overpass, face down on a filthy to he’d spread out for himself the night before. A fresh bot in front of him, empty. Clutched in his cold fingers. He COUGHS, spitting with his dry mouth. Looking around hi Not even sure how he ended up here.
Dan stands at the ticket counter, looking at the crumpled bills in his hands. His hands SHAKE, he’s DIRTY. Exhauste
How far can I get for... He counts out the bills.
Close on the bus sign: FRASIER, NH. Passengers board quie and Dan is among them. The last of his cash apparently we to the BOTTLE he clutches, along with his beat-up knapsac

EXT. ABRA’S HOUSE, BACKYARD - AFTERNOON DOZENS of kids and parents pack the yard, decorated for Abra’s birthday party. David and Lucy watch Young Abra, dressed in a birthday tiara and carrying her STUFFED BUNN run toward them holding out a handmade card.

Mommy! I made this for you -- It’s a secret card! Abra bounds away, toward the MAGICIAN who is gathering th kids at the end of the yard. Lucy looks down at the card. Just a simple word: hELL© The MAGICIAN holds out a red TOP HAT to the kids.
Nothing up my sleeves, nothing up my sleeves... He reaches in, pulling out a WHITE RABBIT. The kids clap giggle, and he hands it to Abra.  19. MAGICIAN (CONT’D) Abracadabra!
I know magic too!

Well you get to hold him, birthday girl. She pets the bunny, watching. He turns over the hat, and SILVER SPOONS fall out. The ki laugh, delighted, as he picks them up and starts HANGING ON HIS FACE, the last one balanced on the tip of his nose
I can do that.
That’s nice, sweetie.
The party is over, the last of the kids trickling out. Da and Lucy clean up as Abra plays with the last of her frie David frowns at the birthday cake.
We can forget nap time.
Just a few more hours. Say it with me, just a few more hours -- She smiles at him, heading through the open sliding glass door into the house. As he carefully scoops up the cake -

(alarmed) David... INT. ABRA’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - MOMENTS LATER David enters the kitchen, where Lucy stares. White as a sheet. She’s pointing... THE SILVERWARE DRAWERS ARE ALL OUT, as though they SHOT O FORKS AND KNIVES ALL OVER THE FLOOR.
What the hell...  20.

Dave... Lucy POINTS AT THE CEILING. He follows her gaze -- ALL OF THE SPOONS are hanging from the ceiling. Dangling, though magnetized. Their tips barely touching the plaster They STARE at it as Abra enters. Stuffed bunny in her han
(proud) Abra... cadabra!
Honey, did... did you do this? Abra’s smile fades. Her lip starts to quiver.
Am I in trouble? They stare at her, not sure what to say -- as she STARTS CRY, to REALLY LET LOOSE --

head_text.subj: ALL OF THE SPOONS FALL DOWN AT ONCE, CRASHING TO THE FLOO

text: Dan STARTLES awake in his seat. SENSING SOMETHING, someth that woke him... as though REACTING TO THE FALLING SPOONS

Rose STOPS in her tracks as she heads toward her RV, also SENSING SOMETHING. Looking over her shoulder. A passing thought, but something... some thing... INT. ROSE’S RV, LONG ISLAND - MOMENTS LATER Rose steps into the trailer. The moment forgotten as she heads toward ANDI, who is just waking up on the bed.
Hi there, sleepyhead. Sorry, I had to sleep you pretty hard, you’re a tough one. Willful.  21. Andi sits up, rubbing her head. Taking in her surrounding
You know I checked... six men, in three months. With those little snakebite tattoos on their cheeks. You've been busy. (beat) Snakebite Andi, that’s who you are. So who am I...
You're some crazy bitch that kidnapped me -- Rose holds up a finger. One finger, and Andi is SILENT.
Just the truth, from now on. You’1l only say the truth.
(beat) You’re the most beautiful woman I've ever seen.

Well golly. Works a little too well, don’t it. Here’s the deal, Snakebite Andi. You’re a pusher. You can push people, and we haven't had a pusher round here for a little while so I’m gonna offer you a deal I haven’t offered anyone in almost forty years.
No way you’re forty.
How old are you, darling?
Fifteen.

Fifteen. God, what an age. The Springtime of your womanhood, isn’t it, you're not a girl anymore but you don’t have a single dent yet, either. Gravity hasn’t even noticed you, not at fifteen. (beat) Men, though...  Andi lowers her head.

No! No shame, and you paid that back, didn’t you. What I’m offering, Snakebite Andi, is just that: Springtime. Springtime forever. Ten years from now, you’re still fifteen. A hundred years, maybe you’re seventeen. Live long, stay young. Eat well.
Sounds too good to be true.
I know it.
So you and your friends out there -—
They're not my friends, they’re my family. We’re the True Knot, dear.
(snickers) True Knot.
What’s tied can never be untied. Andi laughs. Rose, though, isn’t laughing.
Do I have any other choice?
Only bad ones, dear. But it’s better if you want it. Makes the turning easier.
(beat) Does it hurt? Rose smiles, and lies.
Not at all. cur 22.

Dan steps away from the bus station. Tired, beaten. Shuff through town, not even sure where he’s going. It’s MAIN STREET New Hampshire, the evening hours seeing the street mostly deserted. A small town, with character. He stops at a sign: VISIT TEENEY TOWN! FRASIER’S SMALL WONDER. He looks beyond it, smiling to himself as he beho Teeneytown. It’s a MINIATURE REPLICA of the very street h on, a tiny representation of the town he’s in. Around it, a SMALL TRAIN - designed for toddlers - restin idle on its tracks. Dan smiles. It’s strange, but welcomi at the same time. He crouches, examining the locomotive.
You like it? Dan spins to face BILLY FREEMAN (late 40’s, kind.)
Sorry, I was just -

That’s okay, people love to look at it. Model train buffs, usually. We keep em away in the summer when the place is jumpin’, but this time of year there’s no we, just me. And I don’t mind. (holds out his hand) Billy Freeman. Town maintenance.
Dan Torrance.
Just off the bus? Or you ridin’ your thumb?
Bus. What does this thing have for an engine?
Now that’s interesting. You ever hear of the Chevrolet Veraneio?
Brazilian Suburban, wasn’t it? Turbodiesel.  24.
That's right! Instrument panel’s from a Suburban too. Seats I put in myself. (beat) What brings you to town, Dan Torrance?
Not sure yet.
Not many take the bus this far North, less they’re looking for work. You lookin’ for work?
Yeah, I am. Place to stay, too.
Change of scenery? Or you running away from something? Don’t mind my asking, I hope. New face is all.
(beat) Running away from myself I guess.
Yeah, I know that look. Pretty well, sorry to say. (smiles) Runnin’ away from yourself’s a pickle. You take yourself with you, wherever you go.
Ain't that the bitch.
(considering) I know Mr. Kingsley, from the program, he helps folks out now and again, if they’re worthy of help, that is. You got references?

A few. Mostly janitorial, hospital orderly stuff.  25. INT. DAN’S ROOM, ELLIOT STREET - EVENING Dan stands by as MRS. ROBERTSON (40’s) gives him a tour o the LOFTY ROOM, at the top of the building. A view of the mountains, a simple room. A bed, a bath. Billy watches on

Rent’s eighty-five a week, payable upfront. Billy paid your first two, the rest are on you. Once you start getting paid at Teeneytown. No pets, no parties, no noise. Dan looks at Billy, surprised. Billy just watches.
I’m a quiet tenant.

Last guy said the same. Math student. Even let him paint the wall all blackboard, so he could scribble his little puzzles up there. She walks to the wall adjacent to the bed. A wall painted over DARK, with CHALKBOARD PAINT. She reaches down, picki up one of several pieces of COLORED CHALK by the wall. MRS. ROBERTSON (CONT’D) (writing) Wasn’t quiet, no sir. Didn’t even paint over this when he left, but I’m glad he didn’t so I can make this easy for you... so you see it every morning, when you wake. She steps back, revealing the writing: “85/wk. BEHAVE.” S walks past him, stopping for a beat beside Billy. MRS. ROBERTSON (CONT’D) You sure you wanna vouch for this pup?
Pretty sure.
It’s your ass, Billy. She leaves, and Dan looks to Billy. A long beat.  26.
I’m downstairs, ground floor, if you need anything. Find me tomorrow and we'll talk about some work.
Why are you doing this? You don’t know me.
No I don’t. But I know the look, like I said, and... sometimes I get feelings about people. Hard to understand, I guess.
(beat) Easier than you think.

Andi lays flat on a lawn recliner, near the group of RV's The sounds of the waves, a sky full of blinking stars overhead. A FIRE BURNING in the center. She’s nervous. Around her, the members of the TRUE KNOT stand. Rose in h hat, Crow beside her. Apron Annie, Barry the Chunk, Silen Sarey watch as Grampa Flick regards them with ancient eye
No fear.
Who are these people -
You'll find out, after. But this here is Grampa Flick, and he’ll lead us. No fear, understand? Rose nods to Grampa Flick, who steps forward.
We are the True Knot and we endure.
Sabbatha hanti.
We are the chosen ones.  27.
Lodsam hanti.
We are the fortune ones.
Cahanna risone hanti.
What is tied cannot be untied. Here is a woman. Would she join us? Would she tie her life to our life?
Say yes.

Yes. Rose reaches down, lifting a SILVER CANISTER. Almost like THERMOS, but older. STRANGER. She holds it near Andi’s fa Rose TURNS THE VALVE on the canister. A small, rueful sig and a PUFF of silver MIST escapes. But it doesn’t dissipa into the night air... IT HANGS.
This one’s special. Her name’s Violet, and there’s not much of her left... she tastes like flowers. Rose gently purses her lips, BLOWING the pocket of mist softly. It FLOATS around Andy’s face.
Breathe deep. After a beat, Andi BREATHES IT IN. ROSE HOLDS HER DOWN.
Embrace it. It’s the only way through. Andi SCREAMS in pain, shaking VIOLENTLY in the chair.
Take steam or die. Andi CONVULSES, and as they stare at her, HER SKIN BEGINS CHANGE -- BECOMING TRANSLUCENT, TRANSPARENT, in FLASHES - CYCLING between human and something else --  28.

head_text.subj: WE CAN SEE HER SKULL, SCREAMING UNDER THE SKIN OF HER FAC

text: Dan is asleep in bed. Out the window, snow falls hard. A SHUFFLING SOUND in the corner slowly stirs him. He opens eyes. Squints into the darkness... there’s nothing. But he becomes aware of something else. FLIES, buzzing ar him. He realizes SOMEONE HAS THEIR ARM DRAPED OVER HIM -- DEAD ARM, ROTTING. FLIES CRAWLING ALL OVER IT. He carefully reaches down, trying to LIFT THE ARM away, w he starts to roll over TO SEE THE ROTTING SKIN of A NAKED YOUNG WOMAN laying in bed beside him. HE SLOWLY tries to drop to the floor beside the bed, almo extricating himself from her grip when HER DEAD HAND GRAB HIS ARM. He SHOUTS, and she slowly ROLLS OVER TO FACE HIM IT’S DEENIE. Eyes clouded over, BLOOD AND VOMIT coming fr her nose and mouth. LIKE SHE DIED OF AN OVERDOSE. She SMI and when she speaks, she’s speaking through PHLEGM.
They haven’t found us yet. He GASPS. CLOSES HIS EYES -- BUT SHE GRIPS HARDER, and wh he opens his eyes HER FACE IS INCHES FROM HIS OWN.

They were used to hearing him cry, ‘cuz I left him alone so much... so they didn’t do anything, and they haven’t found us yet... He stares. The flies CRAWL OVER HER OPEN, SIGHTLESS EYES. Dan notices something else -- A SMALLER HAND, also PALE A ROTTEN, CLINGING TO DEENIE. She reveals the TODDLER, cudd against her. DEAD AS WELL.

Mama -- Dan SCREAMS. And SCREAMS. And the room is EMPTY. He SHAKE the ground, overwhelmed with horror. CRAWLS FAST toward t bag at the foot of his bed, GRABBING FOR -- THE BOTTLE OF WHISKEY, half full, inside. He PULLS OFF TH CAP, bringing it toward his lips --  29. BUT STOPS THIS TIME. STARES AT IT. FOR A LONG TIME...
A hand KNOCKS on a door. After a few long moments, the do opens, revealing BILLY. Blinking at the late hour. Dan st in the doorway, TEARS ALL OVER HIS FACE. AT ROCK BOTTOM.
You said you knew my look. What’d you mean?

You're sick and you’re tired, I can see that much. But are you sick and tired of being sick and tired? After a long beat, Dan says the words he’s struggled to s for so long. The most important words he’1ll ever say.
I need help. Billy nods. Smiles gently.
Come on in. Let’s talk about it. He steps aside, and Dan comes into the room.
A group of RECOVERING ADDICTS sits in the dimly lit churc basement. At the podium, the moderator DR. JOHN (mid 60's stands to speak, leading the group in the prayer.
God, grant me the Serenity, to accept the things I cannot change, courage to change the things I can, and wisdom to know the difference. Dr. John smiles at the room, holding out a box of CHIPS.
Anyone here have a year? Six months?  30. An ADDICT gets up, applause as they take their chip.

Three months? Thirty days? (as someone approaches) Congrats brother. He looks out at the group. DR. JOHN (CONT’D) And now for the most important person in the room. Anyone here a newbie? Someone got 24 hours? Reveal DAN, sitting beside Billy. Tears in his eyes. Bill smiles, encouraging, and after a moment, Dan STANDS UP.
Dan and Billy stand by the coffee machine, looking down a the ONE DAY CHIP in his hands. Turning it over. Around hi small talk and handshakes, some hugs. Dr. John approaches, pouring his coffee.
Billy says you’re new to town.
Dan.
John.
Doctor John’s been serving the town most of my life. Delivered my little brother.
Small towns. How you holding up Billy?
Train’s still runnin’. Dan notices Dr. John rubbing his wrist, frowning.
You okay?  31.

Yeah, just... lost something. Emma’s gonna kill me. Well good to know you, Dan. Come back. Hope to see you again soon. They SHAKE HANDS. And in that moment, Dan KNOWS SOMETHING watches Dr. John walking away.
Good man. Really holds us together, got a gift for -
Hang on. He follows Dr. John, reluctant.
Hey Doc... your watch. Dr. John stops. Turns, looking at him quizzically.
You lost your watch. You were worried about the kid with Goocher’s.
(beat) What?
The kid. Goochers? Glutchers? Some sort of bone thing.
(long beat) Gaucher's disease.

Yeah... the terminal ones always bother you, and you washed your hands, the hospital bathroom, you left it on top of the soap dispenser. Your wife gave it to you, it was your wedding present. Dr. John stares. Not sure what to make of this.
Check on top of the soap dispenser. Dr. John nods, and starts to walk away. Dan sighs.  32.
How’d you know that?
CLOSE ON the WATCH, back on Dr. John’s wrist.
Wish I could say. Lucky guess.
Guess my ass... (beat) Billy said you have orderly experience.
That’s right.
You working right now?
Few shifts at Teeneytown. Helping with the train, couple hours a day. Dr. John sits back. Considering.
Well listen, I owe you a debt. However you did it. (beat) I do three days a week at Rivington House. Hospice. Tough to find good orderlies, tougher to keep ‘em.
That sounds good to me, sir.
Dying people don’t bother you?
We're all dying. Whole world’s a hospice with fresh air.
Okay, then. Done. Because you’re a friend of Bill’s.
Billy’s got a lot of pull in this town.  33.
(laughs ) Not Billy. Bill. We’re both friends of Bill’s; Billy is too.
I don’t get it.
Keep comin’ to the meetings. You'll figure it out.

Andi lays on the recliner, the sound of the surf starting bring her back. She blinks into the sun. The True Knot ar enjoying the beach, looking like relaxed campers. Grillin reading, enjoying the sun and the sand. As they see her, SMILE. Some CLAPPING.
Well hi there. Andi blinks. Rose’s hat almost blots out the sun.
How... how long was I...
Few days.
You said it didn’t hurt.
Doesn't now, does it.
I felt like I was dying --
You did.
You brought me back.
Couldn't have done it on my own. You wanted to come, so you came. You'll feel better when you eat.  34. She sits beside her, touching her knee. Gently.
Am I still human?
Do you care? (beat) You’re home. You’re where you belong.
Lucy tucks Young Abra into bed. Puts the bunny in her arm
There you go.
(off her frown) What is it? Lucy doesn’t answer. YOUNG ABRA (CONT’D) (realizes) You're scared of me.
We love you more than anything in the world, you hear me? Anything.

I didn’t do the spoons. I just pretended it was me but it was the real magician. From the party, it was a birthday party trick he did for me and you and daddy shouldn’t be scared, it wasn’t me. It’s a clumsy lie. A child’s lie... but a kind lie. And p of Lucy appreciates it, even though she knows better.
Goodnight, my heart. She kisses Abra, and leaves the room.
Dan MOPS THE FLOORS of the darkened halls. Sparely decora patient rooms lined up left and right. As he does, he alm mops over a CAT, who scuttles out of the way.

Sorry, Azzie. The cat moves down the hall, SCRATCHING at a patient’s do before pushing it open and slipping inside. Dan moves alo lost in his work, as he passes the room. Glances inside. An elderly PATIENT (80’s) lays on the bed, and Azzie the perches at the foot of the bed.

C'mon, leave him be. The cat doesn’t budge. Shrugging, Dan starts to walk away but STOPS. A feeling comes over him. He turns back, opening the door further. The cat just sta almost like it’s STANDING GUARD. Waiting for something. D looks at it for a long time... and then steps into the ro INT. PATIENT’S ROOM, RIVINGTON HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Dan steps inside, feeling uneasy. The patient STIRS.
Doc? Doc, that you?
(beat) No, it’s... I’m not a doctor. Just cleaning up, you want me to call you a doctor?
C’mere. Please. Dan steps toward him, leaning the mop on the desk. The ma looks SICK. One foot almost in the grave.
Cat’s on my bed.
I can take him out --  36.
No, I knew he would be. That cat... always seems to know when it’s time. Guess it’s time.
No, it’s just Azreel being a silly old cat --
Nope. Been that way since I got here. The cat knows when it’s time to go to sleep, everybody knows that. I’m gonna die. Dan hesitates... then REACHES OUT, taking the man’s hand.
(quietly) Yes. You are. I’ll get someone --
Stay with me. Please. Dan sits back down.
Known it’s comin’. Doesn’t make it less scary.
(long beat) I know what scared feels like. But tell you what, maybe it’s what you said. Just going to sleep. Nothing to be scared of, sleeping. Maybe you wake up some place better.
You’re a strange type of Doctor.
I’m not a doctor.
I think y’are. (laughs ) Doctor Sleep. You'll stay, right? The man sighs, relieved. Looks up at the ceiling.  37.
I’m just scared, Doc, scared it'll hurt or be dark or be nothin’ at all, and I don’t wanna -- Dan CLOSES HIS EYES, CONCENTRATING. PROJECTING...
(in the man’s mind) Nothing to be scared of. The man CALMS, listening as though it’s his own thoughts.
Just going to sleep. Finally. True, restful sleep.
Thank you, Doc. Thank you.
I shouldn’t be here, let me get you a real doctor --

No, this is exactly where you should be. Exactly. (beat) I see my wife... And then, one LONG, RATTLING BREATH. As Dan stares -- A FINE CLOUD OF RED MIST rises from the patient’s mouth. Tendrils of red smoke, gently rising from his mouth and n Dan watches the small cloud of mist HOVER above the bed.. AND DISSIPATES into the air with a sigh. Then, the patien perfectly still. IT’S OVER. Dan watches as Azzie the cat GLIDES DOWN from the bed, ca leaving the room. Heading back into the hallway. Dan sits there for a long time, looking at the man. And realizes, for the first time in years, a PURPOSE.

Dan steps into his room, still in his scrubs. Something different about him now. Something profound. He seems PEACEFUL, settled.  38. He moves to the bed, sitting to remove his shoes... and notices something odd. On the blackboard, ALL OF THE WRIT HAS BEEN ERASED. No more rent, no more “behave.” In its place, a single word: hELL© Dan stares it for a long time. Processing. And then... wa to the board. Picks up a piece of chalk, and writes: “HI”
In her bed, in the dark, Abra GIGGLES. Like she heard him and then, rolls over to sleep.
Dan sits. He stares at the writing for a long, long time. FADE OUT.
The snow piled up. The hotel dark.
We FLOAT through the corridors. The sound of OLD-TIMEY MU coming from somewhere deep, deep within the rooms... echo through the halls, a ghost in its own right...
We float into the ballroom. Toward the FAMILIAR BAR, illuminated from below. No one in sight, but the MUSIC IS COMING FROM HERE. Come to rest in a CLOSEUP of A GLASS OF WHISKEY.
Your credit is fine, Mister Torrance --
CLOSE on an EIGHT-YEAR CHIP... in DAN’S HANDS. Eight year older now (late 30's), CLEAR-EYED and sober. Around him, people CLAP as he takes his chip. He turns to face the ro Legend: 2008
Dan, alcoholic.
Hi Dan. From the chairs, Billy cups his hands to his mouth.
Speech!

I’m not a speech guy, so I figured I'd hold the chip and talk about whatever popped up. So here I am, and... I’m thinking about my dad. I saw a chip like this in his hand, couple of months before he died. 5- month chip, I’m pretty sure. He hurt me once, when he was drunk, broke my arm, then he dried right out. He looks at the chip, and then at the group.

He died when I was 5, so the only way I ever got to know my dad, really know him, was when I went dark. When I drank, to dull the... or every time I wanted to break someone's face. The drinking and the temper. Those things in me, they were his and they were all I could know of him. (beat) But now... now I get to know hima little different. Cause he also stood in a room like this once, wanting to get well. For me. And my mom. He held a chip in his hand, a chip that said 5 months and on that day, anyway, before the hotel... Dan collects himself.  40.

On that day, all he wanted in the world was to stand where I’m standing right now. And here I am. (beat) So thank you, I guess, from us both. This is for Jack Torrance. He takes the chip, returning to his seat. Billy puts a ha on his shoulder as the next person stands. INT. CHARLIE’S ROOM, RIVINGTON HOUSE - NIGHT CHARLIE (90's), stirs in his bed. Soft lamplight beside h as he looks through wrinkled eyelids... TO THE CAT, sitting calmly at the foot of his bed. He sta at it, sighing. Then turns to the chair beside him, where sits. He smiles at Charlie in the warm lamplight. There’s something different in Dan’s demeanor... he is COMFORTABLE in this role now. Used to it. It’s WHO HE IS.
Hi Charlie.
Doc. (beat) I guess I don’t need to ask why you're here, this hour.
Any pain? I can get Claudette to bring you a pill.
Pill won't matter. I’ve heard about these house calls. What a visit from Doctor Sleep really is. So what do you see? Dan puts his hand on the man’s forehead, gentle and calm.
Your twin sons at four. See them?
(beat) I do... I can actually see them...  41.
A Farmall tractor with a striped umbrella over the seat. Five years old, pulling a red wagon --

Lord, look at that -- like a deck of cards, all out of order... (beat) I’m not scared of hell, Doc. I lived a decent life. And I don’t think there’s such a place anyway. I guess I’m scared there’s nothing. There was nothing before, so what if there’s nothing after...
We don’t end, Charlie. I know that for certain. Don’t know much else, but I know we don’t end.
I can taste blueberries, the blueberries my mother used to grow... you taste those?
I do. And I hear Frank, singing on the old radio, on your workbench, by your tools... (singing) Come fly with me, come fly, let’s fly away... Charlie smiles, a tear rolling down his cheek.
If you can use some exotic booze, there's a bar in far Bombay... Come fly with me, let's fly, let's fly away...
Dan steps into his room, peeling off the work day. He tur toward the blackboard, pausing as he sees a message in ch MORNIN’
Been a minute, little pen pal...  42. He walks to the board. Writes a single word in response:
We see ABRA (13 now, the same brightness in her eyes). Sh smiles. Rolling her eyes a little.
Abra! School!
Fine, I know. She pops headphones in as she grabs her backpack, checkin herself in the mirror. Then, she’s off into the world.
The various RV’s of the True Knot are inconspicuously par at another campground. CROW hops out of his truck, passin GRAMPA FLICK as he grills.
Gramps. You seen Rose?

Watchtower. He looks at him as he passes. Grampa Flick looks ILL... h hair almost white. Skin pale. Older than we saw him last. He finds Rose SITTING ON TOP OF HER CAMPER, hat perched o her head. Indian style. Looking out at the trees.
Sorry to interrupt.
Any luck?
Getting closer. We’re heading in the right direction. I just need another day or two. I’1l find him. (beat) But til I do, you gotta open a canister.  43.
We took steam six months ago. Six months, that’s nothing.
Yeah, but Rosie - that kid in Delaware wasn’t so steamy, and it’s already showing. You've seen Grampa Flick’s hair, yeah?
(beat) Yeah.
I don’t think he’s well.
Grampa Flick hasn’t been well since Nixon was in office.
I know. But lately... anyway, we need to eat. All of us. Are the canisters low?
Course not. Just no need to waste one, if you’re close to the kid.
I might need it just to find him. (beat) Used to be more steam in the world.
Don’t be daft. That’s like when Rubes say “fifty years ago, people used to be more neighborly.”

But it’s true, Rose. There’s less steam out there, and weaker, too. I don’t know if it’s their cell phones or their diets or their Netflix or what, but I’m not picking up many scents these days, and the ones I do -
I‘1l open a canister tonight. Just to tide everyone over. He nods. Relieved. Heads back toward the ladder.
You know it, Rose.
Know what?

That's why you sit up here, every day. That’s why you’re always up here, no matter what you tell the others. World’s not as steamy, and you're looking for a whale. Rose watches him go. And looks out at the trees.
Rose looks at the COLLECTION OF SILVER CANISTERS. She sig There’s only a FEW LEFT. She picks up a canister, and tur it over in her hands.

The True Knot have gathered around the campfire. Rose sta at the center, looking out at the HUNGRY FACES of the gro They stare GREEDILY at the canister in her hand. She crouches down, OPENING THE VALVE. A HISS, and the SIL MIST leaks out. Spreading out like an UMBRELLA OVER HER.

Take nourishment, and endure. They gather around, descending on the mist, SLURPING IT I As they do, we watch THEIR SKIN changing, becoming TRANSLUCENT, the GRINNING SKULLS WITHIN visible as Rose s back, watching. Frowning.

Kids playing baseball. Neighborhood uniforms, a boys and girls club. We’re watching the game, nothing unusual... a then we see BRADLEY TREVOR (12) step to the plate. ON THE BLEACHERS: parents and kids watch on. One of the SPECTATORS leans to the man next to him.  45.

Watch this kid - number 19. He’s a natural. Hits it every time. Like he can read the pitcher’s mind. REVEAL CROW sitting behind them. WATCHING INTENTLY. At the plate, Brad smiles just as the pitch is thrown... SENDS THE BALL SCREAMING over the shortstop’s head. The c CHEERS, and Crow smiles. SPECTATOR (CONT’D) See? You watch, one of these days some talent scout’s gonna get wind of Brad, there. You watch. Behind him, Crow just smiles. He already has.

Brad walks along the road, LONG ROWS OF CORN on either si of him. Still in his uniform, carrying his bag and his gl Walking home, smiling. Behind him, we realize a VEHICLE IS APPROACHING from the distance. A VAN. It slows behind him, and he STEPS TO THE SIDE of the road to let it pass. It pulls up beside him. Barry leans out of the passenger window.
Hey! 19! Just saw your game, you’re ready for the majors! Well played!
(wary) Thanks.
You heading home? Hop in, I'll give you a ride. Brad keeps walking, the van keeping pace.
It’s real close, I’m good. The sliding door opens, and Snakebite Andi leans out.
It’s okay. Brad STOPS walking. Staring at her.  46.
We're friends. You wanna hop in, we'll take you right home.
You can take me right home.
You trust me.
I trust you. He climbs into the van, and the door closes behind him. Driving calmly away, past the rows of corn.

The vehicles of the True Knot are parked at the old plant Nothing around them for miles. They all watch on as Barry gently lays Brad in the center of the circle. He’s bound DUCT TAPE, and he’s WEEPING.
Please take me home... I won’t tell. I won’t tell. Please... Barry PICKS UP THE GLOVE. Number 19 carved into the leath
Number 19. Kid, you were good. Barry PUTS HIS HAND into the glove, TRYING IT ON as Rose drops to one knee beside Brad. Touching his hair.

It’s not personal. Rose steps away from him, looking out at the others with smile on her face. She steps toward Andi, who watches as hands rose a SMALL KNIFE. Short, but VERY SHARP. She starts walking back toward Brad, who notices the knif
Are you going to hurt me?
Yes.  47. As the group tightens their circle around him, they hold flashlights so that Rose can sees what she’s doing.

Pain purifies steam, dear boy. Fear, too. So you understand. And just like that, she brings the knife to his torso. We STAY ON BRAD’S FACE as his eyes go wide, and we hear a fa SLICING SOUND. He SCREAMS, LOUD. SO LOUD. Rose sits back, looking at his mouth and nose. Frowning, reaches down and GOES BACK TO WORK, her hand moving off- screen as Brad’s scream becomes GUTTURAL. PRIMAL. And then, as his scream of PURE AGONY starts to cease -

head_text.subj: A TINY CLOUD, SO SMALL, OF SILVER STEAM RISES FROM HIS LI

text: Around him, the members of the True Knot GREEDILY LEAN

head_text.subj: FORWARD, THEIR FACES STARING DOWN AND BLOCKING OUT THE SK

text: Good. Good start. Brad pants. Eyes wide with shock and pain. His eyes trave down, to where Rose clutches the BLOODY KNIFE.
Please -
We're just getting started.
Abra is ASLEEP IN BED as we PUSH INTO A CLOSEUP. Her brow furrows. She’s having A BAD DREAM.
(asleep) No... no...

Brad's SCREAMS CONTINUE, becoming harsh BARKS of pain. Al inhuman. His eyes are wild, BLOOD SPRAYING up onto his ch and cheeks from Rose’s work below.  48. Another small CLOUD OF STEAM rises, and again the True Kn LEAN DOWNWARD, almost like a football huddle, BREATHING GREEDILY as the steam spreads among them --

head_text.subj: THEIR SKIN BECOMING TRANSLUCENT, JUST FOR MOMENTS, REVEAL

text: BRAD SCREAMS AGAIN underneath them, but it is pointless.
Abra BURSTS UP in her bed, HYPERVENTILATING. Panicking. Trying to shake the dream.
Stop... stop... stop... She shakes her head, FREAKING OUT. Squints her eyes,

head_text.subj: A KNIFE IN A BLOOD-SOAKED HAND, OVER A BASEBALL JERSEY.

text: BRAD’S SCREAMING FACE. THE TRANSLUCENT, GRINNING SKULL/FA

head_text.subj: OF THE MONSTERS LEANING OVER HIM, EYES SPARKLING WITH GRE

text: And a WOMAN, IN A TOP HAT. WHO SLOWLY TURNS TO LOOK AT HE EXT. ABANDONED ETHANOL PLANT — CONTINUOUS Rose suddenly STOPS HER WORK. Looks over her shoulder. As AWARE SOMEONE IS WATCHING HER... Crow notices her express
(quietly) What is it? Rose just looks up at him. Brad STARES at the sky. Tears blood all over his face.
(weak) Just kill me...
Soon, dear. And then, her hands go back to work, and again, his BARKS AGONY fill the night as the Knot huddles around him, gree waiting for the next morsel of food to rise from his mout
Abra starts SCREAMING HER HEAD OFF. THRASHING ON THE BED. SCREAMING LIKE BRAD is screaming, so many miles away. The lights TURN ON, and David and Lucy RUN IN, TERRIFIED.
Abra! Abra!
Dan is asleep in his own bed, when A BLAST, A SHOCKWAVE, FOLLOWED BY A LOUD CRACKING SOUND as Dan HITS THE FLOOR, HARD. GRABBING HIS HEAD, in PAIN.
Rose SPINS WILDLY over her shoulder. She FELT IT TOO.
Dan struggles to his feet.

Jesus! He stands, not even noticing that his NOSE IS BLEEDING. H eyes go to the mirror on the wall by his headboard -- WHERE SOMETHING TAKES HIS BREATH AWAY. He stares. All his breath stopped in his head. In the mir he can see the CHALKBOARD WALL reflected... A WORD CRACKED INTO THE VERY PLASTER, LARGE AND BOLD.
He stares at it, and slowly turns away from the glass, to the wall, where the word MURDER stares down at him. He walks to it, very slowly.
Okay. Okay. SCARED, he picks up the chalk. And writes one word back:  50.
He slowly turns, walking back to the bed. Shaking, he sit down, and makes himself look back at the wall, where the answer has already appeared in chalk. BASEBALL BOY.
Brad stares ahead as his body finally GIVES OUT. A long D RATTLE from his throat, and the Knot lean closer, GETTING LAST OF THE STEAM as it rises from his mouth. Sucking it Rose sits back.
Damn, I thought he had another few minutes in him.

He made it three hours, we can’t complain. She picks up a silver canister. She looks up to Grampa Flick... WHOSE HAIR IS A LIGHT BRO AGAIN, the silver long gone. His wrinkles seem BETTER, smoother. He looks TEN YEARS YOUNGER, EASY. As they disperse, Rose PRESSES ON THE BOY’S CHEST, lookin for little traces of steam that might be hiding inside. S holds the canister, and the steam rises.
Abra rocks back and forth, sobbing as her parents hold he
They killed him. They killed him...
Dan sits on the bed, looking at the word on his wall. Pal scared. Over his shoulder, that familiar word in the mirr

Rose and Crow finish BURYING THE BODY in the dirt, as the morning sun creeps up. The others are inside their vehicl resting, ready to go. She shovels a heap of dirt onto the growing pile. Almost done. She sits back, resting her head on the handle of th shovel. And after a long beat...
We had a looker. Crow stops. Turns to her, slowly.

Help... He leans forward.

I’m going to try something. You're weak, and he’s blocking you, I could barely hear you... I need you to trust me. Okay? Okay? She nods. He reaches out his hand, toward hers. She STRETCHES, trying to touch his fingertips with her own...
Crow drives along. Behind him, Abra SITS UP in her seat. Staring right at him. He glances in the mirror.
Awake again, huh? Might need to dose you at the next rest stop.
Where are we going?
You know where. Abra looks around.
Fuck. I feel... hung over.
Told you. It’s good shit.
Haven't felt hungover in years. And you know I don’t miss it. Not even a little. Crow pauses. Looks at her in the mirror.
(looking out the window) West... staying off the major roads, huh? Smart. She sees a sign. CROWNVILLE, 10 MILES.
Crownville. New York. Crow stares. Looks closely. Abra looks back at him in the mirror, but her EYES ARE DIFFERENT. COLDER. ANGRY. AND THEY’RE BROWN. NOT BLUE.
(quietly) Who are you?
I’m the guy that killed your friends.  108. Crow freezes. Isn’t sure what to do. Clenches up, like a walking through a mine field.
Well nice to meet you. Neat trick... haven’t seen this one before.
Wanna see one more? Crow slowly REACHES for the gun at his hip.

Don’t suppose Rose is gonna be happy about any of this. And when that woman gets mad... Well, seems to me you know enough to know you might wanna sit this one out. Count your blessings, go on your way. Abra reaches around, checking her SEAT BELT. She LAUGHS.
What’s so funny, friend.
Well, it’s just... arrogance. Arrogance, really. But it makes sense. If you think you’re gonna live forever, stands to reason... She grins at him.

Of course you wouldn’t wear your seat belt. Crow glances down. His belt UNBUCKLED -- Abra THROWS HER HANDS OUT, JERKING THEM TO THE RIGHT -- THE STEERING WHEEL JERKS TO THE RIGHT AS SHE DOES --—  109.
The Van SWERVES FROM THE ROAD, through the guard rail,

Dan JERKS AWAKE on his bedroom floor, the momentum of the CRASH sending him FLYING BACKWARD against his bed --
-- Rose DROPS TO HER KNEES, SCREAMING IN PAIN AND SHOCK..

(weak) Dan? Dan? She gets out of the car. Walks toward the SMASHED HOOD -- sees CROW, CRUMPLED ON THE GROUND. CYCLING. She crouches down next to him. He stares at her, SHOCKED

Hang tight, Abra. I’m coming. He grabs his keys, and runs into the night.

Alright, bitch-child. Alright. Rose gets up, going to the CANISTERS OF STEAM. THE LAST O THEM. She TEARS THEM OPEN with her hands, GORGING HERSELF THE STEAM that comes from them. Pulling it all in. INT. DAN’S CAR - AFTERNOON Abra WAKES UP in the passenger seat. Dan is driving. She looks out the window...
I’m sorry, I dozed off.
You earned it.
Where are we?
Ohio.

(long beat) Colorado.

(beat) She's going to keep coming.

Always. This only ends if we end it... and I don’t think we can beat her. Not by ourselves. (beat) There’s a place. It’s a dangerous place, for people like us.
The place you told me about. The hungry place.
That’s right.

Because if it’s dangerous for people like us... and it is... I expect it’s dangerous for people like her. Maybe even more so. They drive in silence.
Good. She’s following us, you know.
That’s good. Let her. (beat) I’m sorry. About your father. Abra nods. Takes a beat... and STARTS TO CRY.

Iowa. Where this started.

Hi Mom...
Lucy sits on the curb, surrounded by POLICE. They’re goin through her house. Tears on her face, devastated and shoc

Come home... my god, Abra, what’s happening...

Who did this?!

I will.
Okay. She rolls down the window, and THROWS THE PHONE OUT.
Abra looks up at the IMPOSING MOUNTAINS as Dan finishes gassing up the car. A LIGHT SNOWFALL on the ground around them, more on the mountains above. He climbs back inside.
Not too much further. Up the mountain.  115.
Are we going to win, Uncle Dan?
We have to. They start driving.

Dan moves down the hallway outside the GOLD ROOM. Realizi there is LIGHT COMING FROM INSIDE...  118. He steps into the double doors, looking past the TABLES A CHAIRS, toward the BROKEN STAGE at the front of the room. then seeing the source of the light... THE BAR. At the far end of the room. LIT PERFECTLY from below, an EMPTY GLASS on the bar. WAITING FOR HIM. And after a long beat, he approaches the bar. Past the formerly grand ball room, now dilapidated. Slow night, Mister Torrance. In front of him, his back to us, a BARTENDER wipes glasse

I was. Most of the time. The bartender turns to him. We don’t see his face, but we Dan’s expression as he’s poured a glass of JACK DANIELS. always knew this day would come, somehow.
On the house.
Thanks, dad. We PULL BACK. Revealing the bartender... it is JACK TORRA (40's). Dressed sharply, the same red tuxedo, the same bl bowtie, that LLOYD wore. Part of the staff now.
I'm afraid you’ve confused me with someone else. It’s Lloyd.
Lloyd.
I apologize, I’m not sure where everyone is. But it’1l pick up.
I know where they are. And you're right, it’ll pick up. (beat) (MORE)

This was your brand, Jack Daniels. I used to see the bottles at home - our real home, before all this. Mom would find them, hidden sometimes. I smelled one once. Smelled like something on fire. Which, I suppose, it was.
Would you care for something else?
No.
What’s the old saying? “The ideal man doesn't smoke, doesn't drink, doesn't get angry --”
“Doesn't exist.”
Very good. If you don’t mind my saying, Mister Torrance, you seem... Put upon.
Put upon.
Ain’t that the way. Man just living his life, trying to do his work, gets put upon. Pulled into other people’s problems, I see it all the time. If you don’t mind my saying.

I'm sorry?

Mom and I. We never wanted to see snow again so we lived in Florida. Tiny place, but comfortable and we were happy. I mean we were grieving, we were traumatized, but there was happiness too. He stares at the drink. Wanting it so bad.  120.

I was twenty when she died. And not my best self, not by a mile. She saw it, saw you, in me, but she loved me through it. Then she got sick and back then I’d see - when someone was gonna die - I'd see flies. Black flies. Death flies, I called them, circling people’s faces, landing now and then and those last weeks she was covered. Her whole face. Could barely see her eyes through them, and I’d try to comfort her but I could hardly look at her and she saw that. Laid there dying while her son... avoided looking... Jack PUSHES the drink gently toward him.
Maybe something warm, to push away such unpleasantries -
Don’t you want to hear? I mean, she was your wife. You loved her in your way, I know that. Don’t you want to hear about her last days? What she said about you?
I think you’ve mistaken me for someone else. I’m just a bartender.
Right. Lloyd the bartender: pouring joy at the Overlook Hotel.
I‘1l pour whatever you'd like, Mister Torrance.

Won’t cost money. It’ll cost me eight years. Eight behind me, and who knows how many in front of me.  121.
Your credit is fine, Mister Torrance. Dan turns the glass. Rolling the booze around within.

When the others started coming back - and they all did, over the years - I expected you’d have your turn. Thought I’d turn a corner and there you'd be. Maybe with the axe. Maybe typing away, hunched over your old typewriter in the other room. Maybe frozen in the snow... but you didn’t come.
Perhaps a bourbon. We have an extensive collection. Dan picks up the glass. Turns it over in his hand. Wantin it, more than he’s wanted a drink in a long time...
“Man takes a drink... the drink takes a drink... then the drink takes the man.” Ain’t it so, dad? I wonder, frankly, what our lives would have been - what our family would have been - without this --
Medicine. Jack stares him down. Something has CHANGED in his eyes.

Medicine, is what it is. A bonafide cure-all. Depression, stress, failure, remorse, it wipes it all out. The mind is a blackboard and that’s the eraser and it’s good, good medicine, Dan. Jack leans forward, takes the glass from him. KNOCKS IT B

One thing, just for him, to warm him up, take the sting out of days of those mouths eating and eating and eating everything he makes. Everything he has. Shout for more, tell you you’re wrong, don’t even bother to say “thank you.” Just eat, and whine until you’re empty and done. He POURS ANOTHER. Pushes it to Dan.
Enough to make a man sick. And this is the medicine. So tell me, pup. You gonna take your medicine? He waits. Dan leans back. Afraid.
I’m not -- 122. Jack SMASHES THE GLASS out of the way. The liquor FLIES O SPLASHING onto Dan’s shirt. Jack stares him down... a warm smile appears, out of nowhere.

Concerned.

I believe I am.

(shrugs ) Nothing. Easiest thing in the world to do, son. Bring her inside. And then... well, accept the things you cannot change. And you and I can sit at the bar, have a drink. That’s what you’ve always wanted, isn’t it? Dan stares at him. About to answer when --
He SNAPS to attention. Looking toward the door.  124.
Dan, she’s here!

Yes, you run, dear. Then I’1l find you. And you’1ll scream for years before you die.

I get it, you’re scared. You should be... you’re the man who killed my Crow, aren’t you. Dan nods.
The others too.
(to Abra) Go. In that moment, Rose GRABS HER EARS as a HIGH-PITCHED RIN erupts in her skull. The room GOES BLURRY, and she STUMBL to one knee. After a moment, she shouts --

(shrugs ) Something happens to the steam, when you rubes get older. It gets dirty. Polluted. You know that, I see the grease all over you. You don’t “Shine” quite the same, do you. Such a gifted boy. Hiding his light under a bushel, for so long. You could live a long, long time. Live well, too. Indulge yourself. No consequence. No hangovers. Live long, eat well.
